awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A simple, rapid field culture test to quantify Vibrio cholerae in drinking water
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a new water quality test that detects and measures Vibrio cholerae bacteria in drinking water samples. The test is an easy-to-use, field-deployable, and selective without requiring a lab, electricity or complex, expensive testing equipment and methods. The technology generates rapid test results in about 24 hours. Cholera is a waterborne disease that people contract when they drink water contaminated by the fecal bacteria Vibrio cholerae. The disease is an international public health burden prevalent in countries with unsafe drinking water and poor sanitation. The water quality test is a surveillance tool that monitors drinking water supplies and sources for Vibrio cholerae, helps prevent cholera outbreaks before they occur, track sources of cholera outbreaks, and evaluates the necessity and effectiveness of water sanitation. This environmental technology will help impact domestic and international environmental testing, water, sanitation and hygiene, and public health. 

This SBIR Phase 1 project will develop novel growth media for the detection of Vibrio cholerae in drinking water. Currently available media do not differentiate between Vibrio cholerae and other Vibrio species. The technical challenge is to develop a field-deployable, direct, quantitative, single-step, culture-based testing method. The project will develop new growth media for two testing methods that generate different types of test results: Most Probable Number quantification and Colony Forming Unit quantification.  Technical hurdles include: refining the composition of the media, optimizing the application of the media for both testing methods, validating both methods with challenging test waters, evaluating media stability and shelf life, and evaluating the media against standard, competing technologies. Successful media will meet all requirements for sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value. Successful media also will have a one to two-year shelf life. The test will be easy for anyone to use in the field without needing a lab or electricity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cholera is a serious global public health threat. The disease is endemic in many countries, particularly in poor and developing countries with inadequate water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) systems and unsafe drinking water. The most affected continents currently are Asia and Africa, with Sub-Saharan Africa being the center of several cholera epidemics and where the risk associated with cholera infection is high. Researchers estimate there are 1.3 to 4.0 million cases of cholera per year globally, and 21,000 to 143,000 deaths worldwide annually due to cholera. Cholera cases and fatalities have been surging worldwide since 2022 and cases are now at an all-time high.

A primary source of Vibrio cholerae (Vc) bacteria is contaminated drinking water. Cholera usually is transmitted by humans when they ingest water contaminated directly or indirectly by the fecal excretions of people infected with cholera. The cheapest and most effective way of avoiding cholera outbreaks is to provide safe, clean drinking water and better sanitation systems. Routine water quality testing is a crucial component of providing safe drinking water and water resources management.

However, drinking water is rarely tested for Vc. There is inadequate capacity of epidemiological surveillance and laboratories in poor, cholera-endemic countries. Existing water quality testing methods for quantification of Vc are lab-based methods that require complex, multi-step culture assays followed by either biochemical, immunological, or molecular assays.

These lab-based methods are rarely applied to routine surveillance of drinking water because they require electricity, expensive, complicated equipment and reagents, and training of advanced analysts. Such resources are impractical or unavailable in poor countries where cholera is present. Field testing environmental water sources outside of labs for Vc is an unmet need in countries where cholera is present.

Through rigorous R&D in the lab, Aquagenx developed a simple, single-step field test for Vc that only detects Vc bacteria while inhibiting the growth of other bacteria in 100 mL water samples. No labs, complicated equipment or highly trained analysists are required.

Routine environmental water quality monitoring with our Vc test will identify cholera hotspots and track sources of outbreaks. It will also help evaluate the effectiveness of WASH interventions such as drinking water chlorination and inform the most appropriate medical interventions as well.

The Aquagenx Vc test will solve an urgent problem, which is the current inability to test drinking water specifically, easily, and rapidly for Vc bacteria in the field outside of labs. Aquagenx field test kits for Vc will introduce a transformative test that fills the gap for a completely overlooked area of WASH and cholera - water quality testing. It will be a powerful WASH surveillance tool for Non-Government Organizations (NGOs) and governments to identify sources of cholera and cholera hotspots, help prevent outbreaks, and help slow the rapid spread of cholera outbreaks. Test result data will better inform NGOs and governments of the most appropriate WASH and medical interventions before, during and after outbreaks.
